properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected to persist until this evening. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T04:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T16:20:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3196101600.2019
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain or drizzle on tap Friday... Periods of rain or freezing drizzle are expected over Southwestern Quebec. Precipitations should begin overnight Thursday night over the Outaouais area and the greater Montréal before reaching Central Quebec during the day Friday. The amount of freezing precipitation expected are not significant but should be enough to make roads and sidewalks icy and slippery. Consider the possibility of getting a head start or delay non-essential travels. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T05:39:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T13:40:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2151121035.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle expected today and possibly tonight into Thursday. Freezing drizzle is affecting the region this morning and may continue for much of the day. Dense fog patches are also possible in some areas. Travel may be affected due to icy roads and reduced visibilities at times. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of snow, blowing snow, and strong northwesterly winds expected Boxing Day evening. In addition, very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Snowfall Amounts: 5 to 10 cm Thursday afternoon and evening. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore Friday morning. Locations: northern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: A brief period of snow and strong northwesterly winds gusting to 90 km/h will develop Boxing Day afternoon and persist into the evening. The fresh snow and strong winds may cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over some areas late in the day on Boxing Day. In addition, a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build on Boxing Day and Boxing Day night. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T11:20:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T19:21:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1917982284.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm through tonight, Boxing Day, and Boxing Day night. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Clarenville and Terra Nova. Remarks: Periods of snow will ease to scattered flurries tonight and then reintensify into snow near noon on Boxing Day. Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h will persist through tonight and Boxing Day and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in exposed areas. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T11:25:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T19:26:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2593363994.2019
Area: Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected tonight. Blizzard conditions will end early Thursday morning as the winds ease and the snow ends. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T09:37:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected later this week. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday and Friday. Remarks: a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build later this week. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tides. The highest water levels are expected to occur on Friday morning, but vulnerable areas may become susceptible to flooding as early as the Thursday morning high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T06:04:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T14:05:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2639363190.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: near 10 cm through tonight, Boxing Day and Boxing Day night. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly 80 km/h, except locally 100 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula. Remarks: Periods of snow will ease to scattered flurries or freezing drizzle tonight and then reintensify into snow on Boxing Day afternoon. Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 80 and 100 km/h will persist through tonight and Boxing Day and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in exposed areas. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T11:22:49-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: near 70 km/h from the northwest. Locations: Areas of the Trans Labrador highway near Cartwright Junction. Time span: Early Thursday morning until Thursday evening. Remarks: Coastal areas as well as the remainder of the Eagle River portion of the Trans Labrador highway can expect roughly 2 to 5 cm of snow on Boxing Day. The public is advised to plan any travel in the above mentioned areas accordingly. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T11:42:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T19:43:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3394810957.2019

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: near 70 km/h from the northwest. Locations: Makkovik and vicinity. Time span: beginning this evening and ending Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Areas most likely to experience poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will be confined to the exposed coastline near Makkovik. Snowfall totals in the Postville area should be roughly 2 to 4 cm. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A frontal system pushing eastward across the northern Gulf of Alaska today will spread significant snow to the Haines Road tonight into Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected with the highest accumulations occurring tonight. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
